instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA: What is PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA? PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA is a 3.3 volt power rail that powers the camera. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
I have a 2013 macbook pro, I changed the left speaker, left it on overnight and battery died and is now not powering on.
All power rails are present, the only two that are slightly off are <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> which read 18.5v. Any ideas?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
Not powering on and all power rails are present, impossible at same time!

Please explain correctly.
Does the board stay on, but no video, nor USB activity present???

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; disconnect any other cable, keep only charger.
Use a macOS pendrive (with Link LED) attached to onboard USB port.
If LED flashes, there is USB activity for sure.

Do not waste time measuring same power rail in different points.
You will get the same voltage; unless trace is broken.

Do not expect a Thunderbolt related voltage, until a device is connected.
Do not search backlight voltages/signals for a board without internal image, nor USB activity.

Battery is charging?
Do you have original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?

Just in case, try known good working BIOS.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
No USB Activity, just flashed new confirmed BIOS and still nothing.
Is battery necessary to power on laptop? I tested battery with mulitmeter and it seems ok, how to test if battery is charging if laptop has no power?
Using Original 85W magsafe 2 
Any ideas?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
"how to test if battery is charging if laptop has no power?"
Monitor <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger and battery, both connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message: Using multimeter voltage DC setting?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
Of course...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should slightly increase, according with battery level.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message: ok just making sure as it wasn't slightly increasing, I watched it for about 4mins and nothing but would this be why it wont power on? Is the battery necessary for it power on?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
These boards are from worst Apple series.
In theory, should start without battery; with proper charger, original 60/85W Magsafe 2.
Post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with charger; w/ and w/o battery connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message: Yeah  this model is total crap, I hate these models. My exact Voltage is 12.89 w/ and w/o battery connected

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
Looks like battery is not recognized.
The value is a bit high, I recommend you to change your multimeter battery.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message: OK changed batteries on multimeter and now its 12.58 w/ and w/o battery connected

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message:
In fact, looking at posted volatges, board turned on; but not working.
May be damaged CPU because of FDMF6808 chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on

If I unplug magsafe, attach battery then plug magsafe back in I get 12.89-12.90. Does that matter?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on
threads.message: I pulled a battery out an A1417 battery and connected to to board with magsafe and monitored  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with multimeter and it slowly climbs, watched it climb from 12.10-12.70

Still not working then?
Tested USB activity on USB onboard port?
